claim: Pangolin scales do not appear to be an effective medicine for curing any conditions.

supporting.text: Scientific studies have found no evidence that pangolin scales contain any medicinal properties that can cure diseases.

attacks.text: Scientific studies have found no evidence that pangolin scales contain any medicinal properties that can cure diseases.
Traditional Chinese medicine has used pangolin scales for centuries, suggesting they may have medicinal benefits not yet identified by modern science.
Some preliminary studies indicate the presence of unique compounds in pangolin scales that could have therapeutic potential.
Traditional remedies often lack rigorous scientific validation, and anecdotal evidence is not sufficient to prove efficacy.
Preliminary studies are not conclusive, and further research is needed to confirm any medicinal properties.
Modern clinical trials and peer-reviewed research are the gold standard for validating medicinal claims, which pangolin scales currently lack.

supporting.text: Pangolin scales are primarily made of keratin, the same protein found in human nails and hair, which has no known therapeutic effects.

attacks.text: Pangolin scales are primarily made of keratin, the same protein found in human nails and hair, which has no known therapeutic effects.
Some traditional medicines use keratin-based substances for their placebo effect, which can still be beneficial.
Keratin may have indirect therapeutic benefits when combined with other compounds in traditional medicine.
Placebo effects are not a substitute for actual therapeutic properties, and do not validate the efficacy of pangolin scales.
There is no scientific evidence that keratin in pangolin scales interacts synergistically with other compounds to produce therapeutic effects.

supporting.text: Traditional medicine practices that use pangolin scales often lack rigorous clinical trials to substantiate their efficacy.

attacks.text: Traditional medicine practices that use pangolin scales often lack rigorous clinical trials to substantiate their efficacy.
Anecdotal evidence and historical usage in traditional medicine suggest that pangolin scales may have therapeutic benefits.
Some traditional remedies have been validated by modern science, even if they initially lacked clinical trials.
Anecdotal evidence is unreliable and subject to placebo effects, making it insufficient to prove efficacy.
Historical usage does not equate to scientific validity, as many traditional remedies have been debunked.
The validation of some traditional remedies does not imply that all such remedies are effective.

supporting.text: The World Health Organization and other health authorities do not recognize pangolin scales as a legitimate treatment for any medical conditions.

attacks.text: The World Health Organization and other health authorities do not recognize pangolin scales as a legitimate treatment for any medical conditions.
Traditional medicine systems in some cultures have used pangolin scales for centuries, suggesting perceived efficacy.
Lack of recognition by health authorities does not necessarily mean inefficacy; it may reflect insufficient research.
Modern scientific studies have found no active compounds in pangolin scales that justify their medicinal use.
Traditional use does not equate to proven efficacy; many traditional remedies lack scientific validation.
The absence of research is often due to ethical and conservation concerns, not lack of potential efficacy.
Health authorities base their recommendations on rigorous evidence, and the lack of recognition is a strong indicator of inefficacy.

supporting.text: Despite historical use in some cultures, modern pharmacology has not identified any bioactive compounds in pangolin scales that could justify their medicinal use.

attacks.text: Despite historical use in some cultures, modern pharmacology has not identified any bioactive compounds in pangolin scales that could justify their medicinal use.
Historical use in traditional medicine suggests that there may be empirical benefits not yet understood by modern science.
Modern pharmacology may not have studied all possible compounds or combinations present in pangolin scales.
Empirical benefits in traditional medicine often lack rigorous scientific validation and could be due to placebo effects.
The absence of identified bioactive compounds in preliminary studies does not necessarily mean they do not exist.
Placebo effects are well-documented and do not provide evidence of actual medicinal properties.
Further research is required to conclusively determine the presence or absence of bioactive compounds.

supporting.text: Some traditional practitioners claim pangolin scales can treat conditions like arthritis, but these claims are anecdotal and unsupported by scientific research.

attacks.text: Some traditional practitioners claim pangolin scales can treat conditions like arthritis, but these claims are anecdotal and unsupported by scientific research.
Anecdotal evidence is often unreliable and can be influenced by placebo effects or confirmation bias.
Traditional medicine practices are sometimes based on outdated beliefs rather than empirical evidence.
Placebo effects are well-documented in medical research and do not indicate actual efficacy of a treatment.
Modern scientific research has debunked many traditional remedies that were once widely believed to be effective.
Double-blind studies are the gold standard for determining treatment efficacy, and pangolin scales have not been tested this way.
Historical use of a treatment does not guarantee its effectiveness, as many past medical practices have been proven harmful or ineffective.

supporting.text: In certain traditional medicine systems, pangolin scales are believed to promote blood circulation, though this belief is not scientifically validated.

attacks.text: In certain traditional medicine systems, pangolin scales are believed to promote blood circulation, though this belief is not scientifically validated.
Modern scientific studies have found no evidence that pangolin scales have any medicinal properties.
The belief in pangolin scales' medicinal properties is based on anecdotal evidence rather than rigorous clinical trials.
Traditional medicine systems often rely on outdated knowledge that has not been updated with modern scientific findings.
The placebo effect can explain perceived benefits from pangolin scales, without any actual pharmacological activity.
Many traditional remedies have been disproven by contemporary research, showing the need for evidence-based medicine.
